com.datasift.dropwizard.util

Class Classes

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.datasift.dropwizard.util.Classes

  • public class Classes
extends Object
    Utilities for working with Classes and reflection.

    • Method Detail

      • newInstance

        public static <T> T newInstance(Class<T> clazz,
                Object... args)
                     throws NoSuchMethodException,
                            InstantiationException,
                            IllegalAccessException,
                            InvocationTargetException
        Creates a new instance of the given Class, using the given arguments.

        A new instance object of the given Class is created, using reflection, providing the given arguments to the constructor.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the Class to return.
        Parameters:
        clazz - the Class of the object to instantiate.
        args - the arguments to pass to the constructor, if any.
        Returns:
        a new instance of the given Class, constructed using the given args.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - if the given Class doesn't provide a constructor that can be applied to the given arguments.
        IllegalAccessException - if the appropriate constructor is inaccessible.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the number of actual and formal parameters differ; if an unwrapping conversion for primitive arguments fails; or if, after possible unwrapping, a parameter value cannot be converted to the corresponding formal parameter type by a method invocation conversion; if this constructor pertains to an enum type.
        InstantiationException - if the given Class is abstract, an interface, an array or doesn't define a nullary constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - if the underlying constructor throws an exception.
        ExceptionInInitializerError - if the initialization provoked by this method fails.

      • newInstanceFrom

        public static <T> T newInstanceFrom(T template,
                    Object... args)
                         throws NoSuchMethodException,
                                InstantiationException,
                                IllegalAccessException,
                                InvocationTargetException
        Creates a new instance of the same Class as the given template, using the given constructor arguments.

        Given an object of type T, a new instance of Class will be created, passing the given args to the constructor.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the object to return
        Parameters:
        template - an object that provides the Class to instantiate.
        args - the arguments to pass to the constructor, if any.
        Returns:
        a new instance of the same Class as template, constructed using the given args.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - if the given Class doesn't provide a constructor that can be applied to the given arguments.
        IllegalAccessException - if the appropriate constructor is inaccessible.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the number of actual and formal parameters differ; if an unwrapping conversion for primitive arguments fails; or if, after possible unwrapping, a parameter value cannot be converted to the corresponding formal parameter type by a method invocation conversion; if this constructor pertains to an enum type.
        InstantiationException - if the given Class is abstract, an interface, an array or doesn't define a nullary constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - if the underlying constructor throws an exception.
        ExceptionInInitializerError - if the initialization provoked by this method fails.

      • unsafeNewInstance

        public static <T> T unsafeNewInstance(Class<T> clazz,
                      Object... args)
                           throws NoSuchMethodException,
                                  InstantiationException,
                                  InvocationTargetException
        Creates a new instance of the given Class, using the given arguments, ignoring visibility.

        A new instance object of the given Class is created, using reflection, providing the given arguments to the constructor.

        The visibility of the Constructor defined by the arguments is ignored and a new instance created irrespective of the defined visibility. This is potentially dangerous, as the API likely makes no guarantee as to the behaviour when instantiating from a non-public constructor.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the Class to return.
        Parameters:
        clazz - the Class of the object to instantiate.
        args - the arguments to pass to the constructor, if any.
        Returns:
        a new instance of the given Class, constructed using the given args.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - if the given Class doesn't provide a constructor that can be applied to the given arguments.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the number of actual and formal parameters differ; if an unwrapping conversion for primitive arguments fails; or if, after possible unwrapping, a parameter value cannot be converted to the corresponding formal parameter type by a method invocation conversion; if this constructor pertains to an enum type.
        InstantiationException - if the given Class is abstract, an interface, an array or doesn't define a nullary constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - if the underlying constructor throws an exception.
        ExceptionInInitializerError - if the initialization provoked by this method fails.

      • unsafeNewInstanceFrom

        public static <T> T unsafeNewInstanceFrom(T template,
                          Object... args)
                               throws NoSuchMethodException,
                                      InstantiationException,
                                      InvocationTargetException
        Creates a new instance of the same Class as the given template, using the given constructor arguments and ignoring visibility.

        Given an object of type T, a new instance of Class will be created, passing the given args to the constructor.

        The visibility of the Constructor defined by the arguments is ignored and a new instance created irrespective of the defined visibility. This is potentially dangerous, as the API likely makes no guarantee as to the behaviour when instantiating from a non-public constructor.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the object to return
        Parameters:
        template - an object that provides the Class to instantiate.
        args - the arguments to pass to the constructor, if any.
        Returns:
        a new instance of the same Class as template, constructed using the given args.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - if the given Class doesn't provide a constructor that can be applied to the given arguments.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the number of actual and formal parameters differ; if an unwrapping conversion for primitive arguments fails; or if, after possible unwrapping, a parameter value cannot be converted to the corresponding formal parameter type by a method invocation conversion; if this constructor pertains to an enum type.
        InstantiationException - if the given Class is abstract, an interface, an array or doesn't define a nullary constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - if the underlying constructor throws an exception.
        ExceptionInInitializerError - if the initialization provoked by this method fails.

      • of

        public static Class[] of(Object... arguments)
        Gets the Class for multiple objects.

        The resulting array of Class objects that are ordered in parallel with the argument list that produced it. This is especially useful for getting a Constructor for a given set of arguments:

        clazz.getConstructor(Classes.of("abc", 123));

        Parameters:
        arguments - the objects to generate Classes for
        Returns:
        an array of Class objects, in the same order as the argument list

      • resolveVarArgs

        public static Object[] resolveVarArgs(Object... args)
        Ensures a variable argument list has been properly passed.

        Sometimes, you want to pass a single array-typed argument to a method that accepts variable arguments. In these situations, that array will be unwrapped in to a list of multiple arguments, instead of a single argument that is an array.

        Example: Classes.of(TableNotFoundException.class, tableName.getBytes());

        Resolving will differentiate a variable argument list from a single argument of the following types:

        • All primitive array types: e.g. byte[], int[], boolean[], etc.
        • Arrays of reference types that are not Object: e.g. String[], java.lang.Integer[], Class[]; but not Object[]
        An argument of type Object[] is considered to be a variable list of arguments, each with their own distinct type.
        Parameters:
        args - the argument list to resolve
        Returns:
        the argument list, wrapped to protect single array-typed arguments

      • getApplicableConstructor

        public static <T> Constructor<T> getApplicableConstructor(Class<T> clazz,
                                          Class... args)
                                               throws NoSuchMethodException
        Gets a Constructor from the given Class that is applicable to the given arguments.

        If the types of the given arguments are not an exact match for any declared Constructors, a Constructor that will accept the arguments (e.g. because they are sub-types of the parameters) will be searched for.

        If the given Class has no Constructor that is applicable to the given arguments, a NoSuchMethodException will be thrown.

        No guarantees are made about the visibility of the Constructor returned; it may not be accessible from the calling scope.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the objects instantiated by the Constructor.
        Parameters:
        clazz - the Class to search for a Constructor for.
        args - the types the Constructor must be applicable to.
        Returns:
        a Constructor that is applicable to the given arguments for constructing objects of type T.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - if no Constructor is found that is applicable to the given arguments.

      • getApplicableMethod

        public static Method getApplicableMethod(Class clazz,
                         String name,
                         Class... args)
                                  throws NoSuchMethodException
        Gets the Method of the given name from the given Class that is applicable to the given argument types.

        If the types of the given arguments are not an exact match for any declared Methods, a Method that will accept the arguments (e.g. because they are sub-types of the parameters) will be searched for.

        If the given Class has no Method with the given name that is applicable to the given arguments, a NoSuchMethodException will be thrown.

        No guarantees are made about the visibility of the Method returned; it may not be accessible from the calling scope. Similarly, the Method may be static or may be an instance method.

        Parameters:
        clazz - the Class to get the Method from.
        name - the name of the Method to get.
        args - the types the Method must be applicable to.
        Returns:
        a Method of the given name from the given Class that is applicable to the given arguments.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - if no Method is found that is applicable to the given arguments.

      • isAssignableFrom

        public static boolean isAssignableFrom(Class[] targets,
                       Class[] sources)
        Determines if the Classs for the given target types can be assigned to from the types represented by the given source Classs.

        Each target type will be matched up with the corresponding source type. If the length of the two arrays differ, they are considered not assignable.

        Parameters:
        targets - the Classs representing the types to assign to.
        sources - the Classs representing the types to assign from.
        Returns:
        true if all source Classes represent a type that can be assigned to their corresponding target Class.

      • isAssignableFrom

        public static boolean isAssignableFrom(Class<?> target,
                       Class<?> source)
        Determines if the given source Class represents a type that can be assigned to the given target Class.

        If the source Class represents null (via Null), it can be assigned to any Class that represents a reference type.

        Parameters:
        target - the Class of the type to assign to.
        source - the Class of the type to assign from.
        Returns:
        true if the source Class represents a type that can be assigned to the type represented by the target Class.
